description.text: This model is a subsequent design based upon the earlier posted model, 'Soap Bubble Chair': http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:21495 My project that creates a chair from the shape of soap bubbles has recently been posted to Kickstarter. A soap bubble evenly distributes curvature throughout its shape, but at the same time equally distributes the structural forces as well. If you could harness this property for a structural system, you could use recycled materials and yield the same strength as high performance steel. This model depicts the chair's shape with actual soap bubbles, rather than in a solid print Anyone who would like is welcome to print the file for themselves, but the model was created to be a reward for my kickstarter. Please take a look and contribute if you want to help out. kickstarter.com/projects/1748240161/soap-bubble-chair Have a look at my website for more informational slide decks and videos that detail the ideas behind using the shape of a soap bubble in architecture and industrial design. mSurfaces.com

Please refer to bubbleModel.stl for reference of the final assembled form.
Print out the backPrint.stl, frontPrint.stl, connector.stl and glue the three together at the base. Then plase the rims in the supportBase, and dip is soapy water.

description.text: Another phone stand which i've started printing in grey ABS as of writing this. The file converted perfectly for me and the triangular openings used to cut down on material use should also print perfectly without support according to recent tests. It's based on a previous thing with a drastically different design and far less attractive features. Recommend printing on a raft with all models especially ABS since excessive heat due to direct contact to the print bed discolors my materials to a white color.

Printer:

3DWOX

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Infill:

15

Notes:

Print in original orientation for best results.

What I kept in mind

For a phone stand I had to consider some things I learned in my first attempt.

For one: A lot of phones have slick cases that WILL slide across PLA and ABS with ease, which isn't the point of a phone stand.

Two: The first model had a rounded center separator which was much to shallow to work with phone cases. This model uses a sharper angle while still, hopefully, allowing the for a second position for the phone/tablet to sit.

Three: The first model was had no support between the weight supporting arch which buckled moderately under weight most phones and tables can't achieve, however, I believe in over-engineering. This model has material efficient triangular braces which make printing easy and proving support without eliminating all elasticity in the model. Hopefully.

Sketchup Make 2017

For detailed information, feel free to email me at [email protected]

Otherwise you probably know i'm fairly new to this and think this model is underwhelming.

Either way i'll gladly accept any opinions on how to improve or redesign my models.

title: FLSun i3 X-axis Motor Bracket Block with Z-stop adjuster

description.text:
Added a bracket for an M3 z-stop adjustment screw and an end-stop on the left side of the rear x-rod. Ensure that the the z-stop switch is installed with the long end of the metal lever towards the mount and gantry extrusion, so that the screw touches the tip of it, and not near the fulcrum and right over the switch button. This way the quarter inch or so travel at the end of the lever is translated into a much smaller, and therefore more accurate, movement at the switch.

Designed to be used with z-axis leadscrew de-couplers (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1804112)

Still have to fix stls, but it slices fine with Cura.

You can calibrate for 15mm bearing holes using these: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2276869

author: cesnietor

title: Streacom BC1 Open Benchtable Vertical Stand

description.text:
The Streacom BC1 Open Benchtable was design to sit horizontally on a table but increasingly there are a number of people that are using it in the vertical orientation for videos and photography as its easier to view the hardware installed. Whilst the BC1 can stand vertically, it was not specifically designed for this and if knocked forward, could tip over damaging both the BC1 and hardware installed. Additionally, resting the BC1 on its side might over time damage the edge or the table its resting on.

As the BC1 is designed to be an Open project and moddable thought printable add-ons, the obvious solution was to design some add-on feet which would solve this problem. The vertical feet designed achieve the following...

  1. Stop the BC1 from being able to tilt forward. The left side foot of the BC1 already provides support to prevent and back tilt.
  2. Raise the side of the BC1 away from the table to prevent any damage to the BC1 or table surface.
  3. Does not require any additional screws to secure to the table and is held in place with the existing thumbscrews which secure the feet.
  4. Give the table a slight additional back tilt again helping avoid any chance of falling forward.

Printer:

DaVinci 1.0

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes
Finished print, cooling down Ready to trim Fitted to BC1, front view. Note that the screw not actually screw into vertical feet, they still screw all the into the BC1 feet Fitted to BC1, side view

Start with the BC1 3D model

The BC1 source files are available here

https://openbenchtable.com/source/

print_settings.Notes:: Assemble an internal power system where the output of the transformer splits to the Pi (solder on power leads to the remote board) and the harddisk (you'll need to get a barrel connector for the power inserter, ensure that the outer sleeve is ground and the inner (tip) is +5). You may find the need to shave a bit off some of the cables to fit it against the power supply with a hobby knife

description.text:
This case will hold a raspberry pi 3 and a 2.5 HDD. Using it I created 12v powered Media centre with LibreElec running KODI so that I could watch TV-shows or movies in my RV without having to bring disks with me or have access to streaming services.

I load the HD up with my ripped DVD's and then just take it with me.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

15

Infill:

15

Notes:

List of parts required to make this whole thing work (i.e. how to build another one)

• Raspberry Pi 3 - https://www.amazon.com/Raspberry-Model-A1-2GHz-64-bit-quad-core/dp/B01CD5VC92/ref=sr_1_2?s=pc&ie=UTF8&qid=1493653657&sr=1-2&keywords=raspberry+pi+3
• Rpi heat sink - https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0159SSK54/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o07_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
• Samsung Micro SD - https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00WR4IJBE/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1
• Tivo Slide Remote - https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00NGXPVLQ/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o06_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
• 2.5 HDD - https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01C4W2P18/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o07_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
• USB to 2.5" HDD Cable -https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00HJZJI84/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o07_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
• USB Power Insert Cable - https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00D84L5IQ/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o08_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
• RPI Power Board and button - https://www.msldigital.com/collections/all-products/products/remotepi-board-for-pi-3 buy the version with the outboard power button only
• 12v to 5v converter - https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00J3MHT1E/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
• USB Right Angle Cable: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00W9BAAXK/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1
• Power Jack (m/f) whatever size works for you case is sized for this: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00EQ1UWX4/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
• Male jack that works with the usb power insert cable (can't recall what size this is)
• Random wire
• Screws (1 2.5x6 for the lid, 3x 2.5x10mm with nuts for the pi mounting, 1x 2.5x?? For the corner with the RemotePi on it, 4x 3x8 for HDD, and 2x 3x10 with nuts for the power supply)
• Case

  1. Assemble an internal power system where the output of the transformer splits to the Pi (solder on power leads to the remote board) and the harddisk (you'll need to get a barrel connector for the power inserter, ensure that the outer sleeve is ground and the inner (tip) is +5). You may find the need to shave a bit off some of the cables to fit it against the power supply with a hobby knife
  2. Setup LibreElec on an SD Card (Follow directions from their site)
  3. Get the hardware MPEG decoder licenses and install
  4. Assemble and boot the pi, leave HDD off right now
  5. While that's installing put your media on the drive (recommend movies under \movies and tv under \tv)
  6. Follow the directions for the RemotePi power board for LibreElec, make sure you follow both the steps for the autostart.sh and the shutdown script
  7. Add the commands this command to Autostart to have the HD idle aggressively:
  8. hdparm -B 127 -S 10 /dev/sda1
  9. Add this command to shutdown to spin down the hard disk:
  10. hdparm -y /dev/sda
  11. Plug the Hard disk in and boot again, add the directories to the library as the correct type, and let it get all the information

This is a mount for 2 of the E3D Aero extruders ( Standard and mirrored.) This is meant to be mounted on a C beam extrusion but it could fit some applications with modification. The stepper motors I am using are NEMA 17 motors with a length of 34mm. I have posted the SLDPRT files so you can edit these to fit their application.

Tap the holes.

All holes in the mounting plate are designed by the hole wizard in SolidWorks. The ones that need to be threaded are the smaller holes and should be threaded for M3 fasteners. You will need 14 of them for this project.

I used these spiral flute metric taps but any will do.
https://www.amazon.com/INHDBOX-Titanium-Coated-Spiral-Metric/dp/B019SWLTWI/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1493696873&sr=8-1&keywords=spiral+tap+drills+metric+set

author: sabharish

description.text:
I made this Hand driver with insertable Screw bits for adjusting my stepper motors without shorting anything out on the PCB. The Driver shaft is 10mm outer diameter, and 6mm inner diameter. The bits are 5.9mm outer diameter. More infill can be used to ensure sturdiness.

Plastic Drivers are good to use on PCB and other electronics because they are non conductive. Whether its adjusting your steppers on your 3d printer or adjusting potentiometers on circuits, This will ensure nothing gets short circuited.

Printer:

Anet A2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

33%

Notes:

If the Bits do not fit Snugly, They can be Scaled to Fit. The smallest bit may need to be filed or sanded to fit the small potentiomers.
Driver - 0.3mm Nozzle , 0.2mm Layer Height, and 33% Infill.
Bits - 0.2mm Nozzle, 0.2mm Layer Height, and 100% Infill.
Cool slide box!!

title: Radial Fan Ring Duct TEVO Black Widow
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
fan duct for a radial fan to mount under the X-beam of the black widow to keep a free view on the nozzle.

tested with the stock extruder (01-2017) with the heater cartridge cables going sideways to the right.

designed for a 15,3 x 19,5mm fan opening (outside measurements)

required materials:

  • 4x20 Bolts (flat head prefered) + Nuts (2x)
  • 5x10 (or 5x15, 5x20,...) + Nut (1x)

I would suggest to print a second one straight away while the first one is used to cool it so you can see the improvement.

Please let me know if you have suggestions.

Have fun printing it and if you like it, feel free to tip me a coffee :-)

Printer:

TEVO Black Widow

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

comments.text: Denkst Du nicht, dass das ganze etwas zu nah an der Nozzle ist und mit der Zeit die Form verliert? Hab Deinen Fan eben mal gedruckt und testweise montiert, bin mir aber nicht sicher ob das wirklich so auf Dauer Sinn macht. Welche Erfahrungen hast Du selbst damit? Danke jedenfalls! :-)
comments.author: matthmu

comments.text: Danke für deinen Kommentar, ist schon nah dran, aber das ists ja auch so beabsichtigt. Die Form hatte meiner nicht verloren. Durch die Luft, die durch den Ring strömt wird er ja quasi ständig selbst gekühlt. Ich hatte ihn so tief wie möglich montiert, damit er möglichst viel Abstand zum heaterblock hatte. ("hatte", da inzwischen bei mir ein gewaltiger 75x30mm Radiallüfter die Arbeit aufgenommen hat:-))
comments.author: matthmu

comments.text: Nochmal als Rückmeldung: Es ist genau das eingetreten, was ich schon geahnt habe. Das gesamte Teil hat sich schon nach wenigen Drucken so verzogen, dass es nicht mehr zu gebrauchen ist. Das Design ist leider nicht das Wahre, da es viel zu nah am Extruder sitzt. Da wundert es mich ehrlich gesagt auch nicht, dass Du selbst es nicht mehr benutzt ;-) Nein, im Ernst, so macht das keinen Sinn. Viel zu eng an der Nozzle, egal wie man es montiert, entweder ist es zu nah an der Nozzle oder zu tief, sodass es aufs Bett drückt oder - wie nun bei mir - über die Druckteile hinweg fegt. Musste ihn abmontieren, drucken damit unmöglich...
comments.author: 1st_snow

comments.text:
Tut mir leid dass es in deinem Einzelfall scheinbar nicht geklappt hat. Ich habe mit dieser Konstruktion ca. ein halbes Jahr lang ohne jegliche Probleme gedruckt und dann auch nur den Lüfter gewechselt, da ich einen größeren wollte.
Danke für die konstruktive Kritik und frohes Drucken weiterhin!
comments.author: matthmu

comments.text: Okay, danke, dann werde ich mal schauen, ob das passt :-) Wie hast Du es denn nun gelöst mit dem neuen? Würde gerne mehr erfahren ;-)

print_settings.Notes:: These are some clips I made to help secure the TUSH spool holder. The holder works fine with out the clips but I like the idea of them being joined for easy moving.

description.text:
6/6/17- Added a revised file for the standard Prusa filament roll my MK2S came with, this works with the wider rolls.

Not really a remix on the design I just added some clips to secure the two sides together. TUSH Clips V4 is a thinner leg, TUSH Clips V5 (which I use) has a longer leg and more secure filament guide storage.

Printed in eSUN PLA Pro with 20% infill at .20 for clips

Great Filament give it a shot you will like it I promise: http://amzn.to/2pqolmN

"Introducing TUSH - The Ultimate Spool Holder v.2. I was using a regular spool holder. Not the most convenient design, if you ask me, because It takes some time to replace the roll. Also, based on 608 bearings, It gives more than requested length of filament since there is no traction. That's why I designed this Ultimate Spool Holder. It is simple, easy, sexy and comfy.
For one spool holder you will need to print four pieces of this. Also, you will need four 608 bearings. Get the cheapest ones. They are available everywhere. This is press-fit design. Just press the bearings into the printed part, and voila, you have The Ultimate Spool Holder! Congratulations!

UPDATE: Version 2 uploaded
This is exactly the same TUSH. Just some fixes. Now Simplify3D ans slic3r should be happy with the model. Cheers"

Printer:

Qidi X-ONe

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.20 to .15

Infill:

20%

Notes:

These are some clips I made to help secure the TUSH spool holder. The holder works fine with out the clips but I like the idea of them being joined for easy moving.

title: 123D Design
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
It's official, as of now these files do not work, but I'll leave them up here in case some code genius can make them work.

NO CREDIT GOES TO ME FOR DESIGNING THESE FILES!!!!! But since 123D Design (and its other 123D siblings that I don't have) are no longer available for download, I thought I'd put the files up here.

123D Design is a great design program that seems to not be very lucrative, I think I can see why. It appears to me to be a free and easier to understand version of AutoCAD. There is also a ruler .stl file included that was designed with this, just so there is something.

Instructions

Save where you can find it again; preferably in the "Program Files (x86) if your computer lets you, unzip ALL folders (including .zips within the .zip), take files in "AAA" and take them out of the folder; deleting it when you are done, delete the zipped versions, and start designing! Please note that this will take awhile to download and unzip, but it's not a 3D file, it's a program, so don't get too disappointed if you have to wait awhile to download this and fix up the files.

author: arifongun

print_settings.Notes:: I recommend using supports, which should just fill the hole for the keystone ensuring a tight snap. Tolerances were based on a 19.54mm x 14.65mm keystone jack with a 2mm gap to snap into. Since printer calibration and keystone measure will differ, prepare to do a little sanding here and there for a good solid fit.

description.text:
This is Thing I created specifically to complement a javascript game meant to be played in a localized settings. It houses a standard Happ type arcade pushbutton (http://amzn.to/2p05U4U) and includes an RJ45 keystone mount. The idea being standard ethernet cable can be used to connect any number of other buttons to a base station housing an arduino or similar device to register and report the button presses to the software.

Teachers with some basic electronics knowledge could piece something together for use in their classrooms by pairing these with a Makey Makey and any PC or Mac to run games or quizzes that would otherwise be too difficult to get a room full of students gathered around one keyboard.

Printer:

qidi tech 1

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I recommend using supports, which should just fill the hole for the keystone ensuring a tight snap. Tolerances were based on a 19.54mm x 14.65mm keystone jack with a 2mm gap to snap into. Since printer calibration and keystone measure will differ, prepare to do a little sanding here and there for a good solid fit.

description.text:
I remixed this because I had less space on my IKEA-Lack table.
I also used a power meter without the need of a shunt so i do not need the space on the right side.
So this thing does not go over the right side boundaries of the Anet A8.
Less material, faster printing.
The PowerPanel is about 9.- Euros incl. shipping.
Search on ebay for : 20A AC Digital Power Panel Meter
Typ : PZEM-021
Link : http://www.ebay.de/itm/191645649246?_trksid=p2057872.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT

My other things for the Anet A8:

  • Case for the PowerPanel-LCD : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2289073
  • Case for the Power-Supply : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2289225
  • Rear Sensor mount : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2306747
  • Front Fan Cover : https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2307700

Please don't forget to post your Makes ...

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

100

Notes:

You can print this rotated 90° to one of the smaller sides without supports. STL included.
Worked fine on my Anet A8 with common PLA.
I turned on my fan to 100% when bridging the top layers. Don't know if necessary.

Cabling is easy and drawn on the back side of the Power Panel Meter mentioned above.

Mounting

Probably the existing screws are to short now and you have to find ones which are 5mm longer ...

title: FPV cover and mount for sony super had fpv cam

description.text: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lgiX5Z2RIXI Just some parts i made for mounting my new fpv camera on my swift2 flying wing. Perhaps someone else find it useful or get an idea from it..

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lgiX5Z2RIXI I made it for the "600TVL SONY SUPER HAD CCD D-WDR Color Board Camera with OSD Menu DNR" camera that i got from http://www.securitycamera2000.com/products/600TVL-SONY-SUPER-HAD-CCD-D%252dWDR-Color-Board-Camera-with-OSD-Menu-DNR.html You will have to break away the pcb frame from it... Here is a good review of the camera by RcModelReviews
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wdqsClsJyUU Here is another type of cover for the same camera made by JelleAtProtospace , have a look at it, perhaps that is more suited for your needs !
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:20730

comments.text: hi, did you look for other designs before doing yours, did you see this one?
comments.author: JelleBoomstra

comments.text: Hi, i did see that a while back, looks very nice.  Do you have any pictures of it on a plane ? I did put a link to it on this page, perhaps it is better suited for other people looking for a cover.. Looks very aerodynamic ! My mount i just copy of my old mount i had on the plane but in plastic, before it was a mess of epp and hotglue.
comments.author: JelleBoomstra

comments.text: I tried that with my SuperFly (my current avatar) and a Muvi camera, but it was very wavy from all the vibration. Have you tried yours yet?
comments.author: PropellerScience

comments.text: I have had it for about a year now, and it have been fine. I have not tried with this specific camera yet. Before i had a kx171 fpv cam, and a #11 keychain cam for recording. Vibrations is a issue on small planes, it is very important to balance the prop and also make sure the motor is balanced.. This is my first flight with it last year: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RL85Ukjis00http://www.youtube.com/watch?v...

Very impressed by the design of the horses,
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:584516
I decided to make a simple but reliable setup for the synchronization of the illumination.
The stepper motor could be a geared DC motor as well, depending what you have in stock. However, a geared DC motor gives a more stable view. The motor runs at constant speed. Th the small neodymium magnets trigger a Hall sensor. If your printer is big enough, you could make the rods for the horses a bit longer and rotate them diagonally on the bed. That's why the SCAD file is included. Your magnets have a different size? Just change it in the SCAD file. There you can also change the shaft diameter. The housing (for a stepper motor) is ready for improvement. That was a quick and dirty design, just to get things moving. The cap with moving cylinders is optional.

As we are looking at Ancient Egypt this term, and will be designing a Shadoof (or Shaduf), I created this to show the children a working model of one.
A Shadoof is an ingenious invention used in Ancient Egypt, and still used today. The idea is simple. You lower the bucket into a water source (the Nile), then lift and tip into an irrigation channel to water the crops you are growing in a nearby field.

title: ergonomic holder for 9.7 inch iPad pro

description.text:
ergonomic holder for 9.7 inch iPad pro

Your back and neck are in danger

Feel tired and hurt when you keep reading web pages or watching videos on your iPad?That's why you can find so many iPad holders on Amazon. But they are not enough. Regular portable holders for iPad just release your neck for a little, and we need a real high holder for long time using.

This model

It is 160 x 80 x 284mm. You can print it on Makerbot Z18, Zortrax M300 or MakerThink Knight / Knight 2.

Compatibility

This version works well with 9.7 inch iPad pro. The slot to hold the iPad is 6.4mm wide, so it's OK for 9.7 inch iPad pro and iPad mini 4 (6.1mm), but can't work with 12.9 inch iPad pro and the "new" iPad.
But I will make more version soon.

About us

I design tools for daily works. MakerThink Knight 2 is the printer designed and produced by us. It's a 300x300x350mm FDM printer. X/Y axis is driven by servo + ball screw rods. So the real Typical Dimension Tolerance is ±0.05mm

title: B2D Extruder - Strong and Silent Bowden Extruder

description.text:
• B2D stands for "Belted Dual Drive". It's a bowden style extruder that has extra grip to filament and is hardly audible during retraction.
  • Preview the 3D model on Sketchfab: https://sketchfab.com/models/8568dba4796e4a238a1051e965c39b2c

FEATURES:

  • Dual drive gear for improved grip, and prevent grinding filament. Frequent retraction is more reliable
  • Belt driven motion hardly generate any noise itself during retraction. The only noise left from extruder would come from the stepper motor vibrating the frame of printer
  • 3:1 gear ratio to increase torque
  • Adjustable compression of a strong spring
  • Modular parts for different combination of drive gear, filament and bowden tube
  • The bowden connector can slide for 3.5mm. Any diameter of drive gear between 7-12mm is applicable
  • Quick changeable drive gears. Can use large gear with slower motor speed for silent operation, and small gears with more torque for super fast extrusion rate.
  • Operation video recording at: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JjQ7FrQe8s4
  • Drive force test with E3D Hobb-Goblin gears, max of 9-10kg (max spring compression. NEMA17 48mm long with 0.55N.m torque, rated current of 1.5A running at 1.25A) at: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QorkxMkFOio

UPDATE:

  • 26/05/2017 - v2 update. Slightly reduced tension of the belt. Raised the parts that could interfere with set crews which sticks out from the drive gear.
  • 23/08/2017 - New stronger base plate.
  • 20/09/2017 - Fixed the Bowden connector for 2.85 being too tight. Adjustable tension for the v3 base plates.

Making Tips
  • The dimensions in the model are optimised for printing at 0.2mm layer height. Printing at other layer heights such as 0.24 or 0.15 would cause Z dimension inaccuracy.
  • Print the 48 teeth pulley at 0.1mm height with extremely slow outer wall speed (under 10mm/s). Use glossy material instead of matte.
  • Retract at all times while printing the frames. Otherwise the filament will ooze during travel and cause under extrusion at perimeters.
  • No support needed for the three frames and bearing holder.
  • Print top and base plate of frame at 100% infill. The compression spring apply massive force to the left side of top plate. Make sure it's rigid.
  • Rub the cylinder pin on hard surface such as concrete or stone to turn it into a D shaft
  • If printing with high temperature filament such as ABS or PC, scale the model larger in X and Y direction in slicer to compensate for shrinkage. For reference, my experience with UP ABS works with 100.3% scale.
  • For Ultimaker 2, add a piece of 1mm silicon sheet between the motor and frame as damper. This will reduce the retraction noise of motor vibrating frame
Bill of Materials

Belts & Pulleys
1 x GT2 6mm Socket Pulley 48 Teeth (printed)
1 x GT2 6mm/10mm Pulley 5mm Bore 16 Teeth
3 x GT2 6mm Pulley 5mm Bore 20 Teeth - 16x16mm, M4 set screw
2 x GT2 6mm Belt 65 teeth - 130mm

Bolts & Nuts
2 x M3x16 Flanged Button Head Allen Bolt
5 x M3x12 Flanged Button Head Allen Bolt
4 x M3x30 (Flanged) Button Head Allen Bolt
1 x M3x20 (Flanged) Button Head Allen Bolt

It's not about inner diameter. The thing with GT2 belt is that each tooth has a pitch of 2mm.
So 130mm GT2 belt absolutely has 65 teeth. 70 teeth belt has a pitch length of 140mm.

I used 25mm/s retraction in the video, with 254 esteps for the 1.8 degree motor. For UM2+, the noise mainly come from motor vibrating frame. comments.text: What is the push force with 1.75mm ?
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text:
I haven't tested the force specifically. It works flawlessly for general speed at 0.4 nozzle and 0.2 layer height so far, no jam or skip whatsoever.
But there are so many variables affecting the max push force before filament slipping or motor skipping. From what I can tell, the belts will not slip or skip at all. The key factors are profile of drive gear and torque of stepper motor. You can try different drive gear for optimised performance.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text:
An extruder is designed to push a filament and to be able to compare different extruders, this must be measured and published. Just specify the kind of filament as it is the only external variable. Adjustment of the spring and current are specific to the extruder, just adjust for the max and give the values.
What is the point of building a complex extruder if there is no or marginal gain ?
comments.author: yyh1002

comments.text: As you are saying testing push force is so important, can you maybe share a link of the standard testing method? Is there a comparision of push force of different extruders anywhere?
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: This is the fisrt time I hear "filament push force" as a extruder benchmark TBH. I don't remember seeing a push force for Bond tech and E3D Titan.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: You push the filament yes ? Now, difficult to measure ? Then measure the pull. The guys who designed the Titan measured it, they are real engineers. When you design something you compute, you measure, standard engineering procedures. I have seen figures, even in Tom's video when he compared a regular extruder to one with two coupled hobbed gears .
comments.author: yyh1002

comments.text:
Ok, dude. I recorded the filament pull test with current drive gears: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=b-ySoZrtW2U
Also have a pair of e3d hob goblin gears on the way. Expecting how those perform.
Any comments?

remixed_from.title: Prusa i3 Improved for laser cut

title: Z3D Improved Z rod clamp for Prusa i3 Improved for laser cut frame

description.text:
Super quick and easy fix to loose z-rods of your twelvepro style MDF/Melamine frame. This should resolve any mechanical instability with the z-rods and improve print quality. Because this frame uses laser cut holes that may become slightly larger overtime. And wears faster when the rods are removed and reinstalled.

You'll need 2 caps and 2 clamps for the top. And 1 normal and 1 mirrored clamp by the motor. You can mirror this in your favourite slicer. So, 5 regular facing parts and 1 mirrored facing, for a total of 6.

You may need to play with scale (also in your slicer) in order to compensate for too much material shrinkage (well know with ABS) with 1 to 2 percent.

Link to source: http://a360.co/2oSIIdw

author: nightlurker

description.text:
This mount is compatible with the genuine E3D v6, Aero and BLTouch. It's designed to be easy to print and install.

The stock stepper motor for the FT5 has been used, although you could create a spacer and use a pancake stepper instead.

The layer fan is a 40mm x 20mm or a 40mm x 10mm.

The mount also allows the full printing area 300x300x400.

I'm still working on the fan duct but extra holes have been added to the mount to make sure it's compatible with new iterations.

2017/05/11 Added fan_v2.stl, fan_front_shroud_v1.stl, fan_front_bracket_v1.stl

remixed_from.author: nistei
remixed_from.title: Vertex K8400 Bottom Fan Duct - Dual

title: Vertex K8400 Electronics Radial Fan Mount

description.text:
As my standard 5 cm fan died and I only have radial fans in stock I decided to remix the design work of Hest and Nestei to fit a radial fan.

To install it you will have to cut the Ty-rap that holds down the ribboncable closest to the mainboard and you'll have to remove the old 5 cm fan, save the screws! Use superglue to glue the radial fan to the printed part, fan side down, as shown in the pictures. When the glue has set the whole assembly can be put in place using, on the printed part side, one of the screws (these are 20mm though) from the old fan (or a 10mm screw will do as well). On the radial fan's side you'll need a longer, 25mm, screw.

Update 2017-05-03: After printing I found out that running the ribbon cable in between the duct and the printer makes it block the airflow... that's why I normally don't post anything I haven't printed and tested yet. So, v2 is here already:
1- One version with the ribbon cable gap closed up, simply run the ribbon cable over the to of the duct
2- Here the same gap is closed but I added a couple of holes and a bracket to run a new Ty-rap through so the ribbon cable running over the top can be held in place...

title: Snoot tube for Sea & Sea YS-D1 / YS-D2

description.text:
In the original design, the threaded bosses are separate from the main body, such that once fabricated they fall off with minimal effort. In short when the original strobe cup body's STL is viewed in a 3D viewer, "daylight" is seen between the boss and the flat surface.

Used blender to move the wall over to form a solid object with respect to the threaded boss.

The remaining tube and aperture adapters are unmodified.

The cup fits over the Sea & Sea strobe latching into two slots on the body of the strobe, where the fit is such that while retention is good it is easy to install and remove without damage to the strobe's body. Note test fit on a YS-D2.

remixed_from.author: rsheldiii
remixed_from.title: Parametric Cherry MX/Alps Keycap for Mechanical Keyboards
String Theory, a string library for OpenSCAD

description.text:
These are my keycap designs for the ErgoDox (or any keyboard).

I have tried to take a step towards the curvature found on the Kinesis Advantage.
I have based my designs on the Parametric Cherry MX/Alps Keycap thing.
The most common keycap profiles are DCS (Cylindrical) and SA (Spherical), however their angle is not pronounced enough.
I basically took the SA profile and tilted the rows at 10 and 20 degrees creating a much larger curve and making the farthest keys easier to reach.

The following enhancements were made:

  • Added multi row text with offset adjustment.
  • Added support for icon designs recessed.
  • Added GSA profile that is more inclined than SA (G is the first letter of my name).
  • Added stem rotation because the Infinity ErgoDox has the long 2x1 and 1.5x1 switches rotated 90 degrees.
  • Added extra support to hold the stabilizer stems for the 2x1 keys at their highest point.

To use this design, download the OpenSCAD files.
The main file is keyboard.scad. It has many, many examples are commented out. Because it take a long time to render each batch, I comment a few back in before rendering the STL files.

The keycap stems fit both Cherry MX and Gateron switches (see pictures: Infinity and EZ).

Printing:
Nothing special needed to print the keycaps.
Maybe a very little filing of inside of the stems might be needed if they are too tight to fit onto the switches. I have used many printers and most fit perfectly out of the box.

title: Triathlon Water Bottle / Tire Holder (seat post mount 27.2)

description.text:
Designed for Triathlon specific purpose but can be used as a cage mount for any bike with 27.2 seat post. Snaps on to seat post then zip ties in place (found that a wrap of electrical tape under it helps it to stay put and not rotate as easy).
Bottle cages mount with #10 x 1/2" screws and nuts, there are recesses to hold the nut from turning so only a screw driver is needed.
The area between the water bottles is meant for a road tube (I like to add tube infiltrator and quick sticks into a zip lock), I have a Velcro strap to make sure it doesn't bail on me if i hit a bump. The out side openings have room for (2) 16g co2 cartridges that snap into place.

Also take a look at the Number flag snaps to post

title: Yuna's Staff
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Yuna's Staff is a recurring weapon in the Final Fantasy series. It is Yuna's trademark staff.

I made this model because a friend of mine was cosplaying Yuna and she didn't have the staff, i'm planning on actually printing it in the future.

Let me know if you like it or have any ideas on how to improve my work in the comments!

This design is also available on Youmagine

I'm planning on only printing the head, the other parts of the model are for illustration purpose only.

The cane of the staff will probably be made out of wood with a marble-effect epoxy finish to simulate the stone-like material of the original staff. The metal parts will be made out of brass and aluminum and will be turned on a lathe.

CNC-gcode or a vector-map for the head will be added later for those of you that own a CNC-machine or want to use a commercial service to get the staff made.

title: Z-Brace 0.5
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
[Disclaimer: Write request for modifications/adaptations in the comments, if many want something done and it's within my power, I may provide it. If you want to create a remix of this design yourself, I will happily provide files and advice.]

This is my take on a Z-brace for the Wanhao Duplicator i3 and probably it's clones (not the plus versions).
I designed this to leave as much open workspace as possible while maintaining maximum stability.
I call this "Z-brace 0.5" because it braces halfway up the Z-tower.
The mod comes with optional adjustable damperfeet.

It's really rigid, easy to assemble and only requires two 250mm threaded rods and some M3-screws and nuts. All parts print without support if you have decent cooling. If you are having trouble printing the threaded parts, there is an extra tolerance version of those parts.

You need to drill 6 small holes in your printer frame (if you are not OK with that, check the Z-brace by AzzA http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:921948), however I'm including a printable "helper" to get the holes right as well as easy to follow instructions.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AglEk3ycHeA

2x M8-250mm threaded rod
6x M3 screws, at least 8mm long
6x M3 nuts

Check your local hardware store or order them online.
I got mine here https://alfa-tech3d.com/en/8-mm-rod/m8-x-250mm-threaded-rod-din-975-bzp-88.html (based in Europe but ships worldwide).

Tools needed

1x 3mm drill bit
1x 2mm drill bit (or smaller)
1x larger drill bit (like 8mm) for deburring
1x square tool (recommended) or a spirit level
1x adjustable wrench or 13mm wrench/spanner
1x 2.5mm hex wrench
1x needle nose pliers

also helpful
1x 13mm socket wrench/bit

1x Z-Console_Left
1x Z-Console_Right
1x BackLeftConsole
1x BackRightConsole
2x UpperFasteners
1x Helper_Left
1x Helper_Right
4x M8-Nut
2x M8_Tall-Nut

4x Adjustable_Feet
4x M12x1.25_Nut
4x DamperPad_Flexible
1x Tool (print in [email protected]%infill, its for reaching the thin M12-nut).

About the DamperPad (print in flexible material):
The way I designed them was to get maximum stiffness against movement in the X/Y direction but allow it to flex in the Z-direction, thus keeping vibrations isolated from your workbench without making the printer unstable. For this to work as intended you need to use "Cubic" infill pattern in Cura (I don't know of equivalents in other slicers, please enlighten me). This makes the infill walls lean 45° which makes it stiff against X/Y-movements and soft against Z-movements. (Yeah I know, quite hypothetical but it seems to work well).

Consoles and UpperFasteners

Resolution: 0.15
Wall Thickness: 1.6

Infill: 33%
Fan: High

Nuts

Adjustable feet

DamperPad

Top/Bottom Thickness: 1.2*
Infill: 20% Cubic!
Note: if you are having trouble getting the infill to connect, increase "infill line width" to 0.5mm and slow down.

*This value is calibrated for the hardness of regular Ninjaflex. Depending on the shore hardness of your particular filament you may need to adjust this value by ±0.1 or ±0.2 (increase for a lower hardness filament and vice versa).
Ninjaflex has a rated shore hardness of 85A.

author: CoreyN

title: Door Sign | "I will be back" Clock

description.text:
This is a simple clock sign for your business to inform customers, when you are out for a few minutes.

Assembly is very simple.

  1. Print main body, minute-hand, hour-hand and tightening wheel.
  2. Using M4 hex screw, join everything together in such order: hour-hand + M4 washer (as separator) + minute-hand + M4 washer + main body + M4 washer + tightening wheel (with M4 nut inserted at the back). Washers actually help to smooth movement, so I really recommend them.

There are two holes at the top of main body for a piece of rope or something like that to hang it.

If M4 nut does not want to go into tightening wheel easily, heat it up a little bit and then push it into the slot.

If something is incorrect, just drop us a comment and we will fix it ASAP.

For more content, please visit http://www.ameralabs.com blog

remixed_from.title: TS 2020 Rail Carriage for Toranado, Prusa i3 Attachments

title: TS 2020 Rail Carriage for E3D Titan, Toranado, Prusa i3 Attachments V2

description.text:
I designed this carriage around the 2020 rail implementation on the Cobblebot so it can mount Prusa i3 attachments and, more specifically, the Toranado 1.1 Precision Geared Extruder found at:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1246951

New feature of this version is that it can now also mount the Reach3D Titan w/ BLTouch mount found here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1747164

You can get the BLTouch in Canada from Canada's official reseller here: https://store.timeshell.ca/index.php?_route_=bl-touch-auto-bed-leveling-sensor&tracking=590a14c30bd67

E3D v6 and Titan Extruder here:
https://store.timeshell.ca/index.php?route=product/search&search=e3d%20v6%20hotend&tracking=590a14c30bd67

https://store.timeshell.ca/index.php?route=product/product&product_id=85&search=e3d+titan&tracking=590a14c30bd67

Although the mount will probably work with the Titan Aero, the BLTouch spacing definitely won't work with the Aero on this mount.

However, it should be able to be used on any printer built on compatible OpenBuilds 2020 rails.

It can be a direct swap for the stock Cobblebot carriage. It is intended to be mounted vertically rather than horizontally but still using the drive belt along the bottom of the rail.

The screws to attach the Toranado should be round with short heads so that the screws don't interfere with the rail.

There is a very thin layer in the larger holes that can be cut or drilled out so that a bridge can be created to print the counter-sink without supports.

Use M5 screws with OpenBuilds wheels. Requires 2 eccentric spacers for the larger holes.

See it in action:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KlZ117GL7VE

Notes:

Better to print with a less flexible filament such as ABS or ASA.

Assembly order:

  1. Attach the mount bracket to the carriage.
  2. Attach the top wheels to the carriage.
  3. Put the carriage in the rail.
  4. Attach the GT2 belt.
  5. Attach the bottom wheels to the carriage.

The purpose of this column is to test for small prints that the previous layer is being adequately cooled before the next layer is printed. The column should be nicely layered and 1cm high. It will print on a slow printer in less than 15 minutes.  
Should the column be garbled this probably means the previous layer is still molten while the next layer is being printed. Try slowing the print speed and/or adding a print cooling fan.

title: Case for Walkera TX5805 VTx and Camera

description.text:
I purchased a Walkera TX5805 VTx to try out FPV on a custom quadcopter. The original paper casing did not work for my design as it was configured to mount on the bottom of the quad. I originally mounted the board directly to the quad with no case. I am pretty competent with LOS flight, but completely loose orientation under the goggles. I try to start low and slow, but next thing I know I'm 80 feet up and headed for a tree. After a few crashes, I decided I needed something to protect the VTx. This thing is the result. An added benefit is that it makes the VTx/camera modular and easy to move between quad builds.

As I am new to FPV and not race qualified yet, I did not have need for forward pitch angle on the camera. Perhaps when I improve, I will create a modified version with appropriate pitch for Fast Forward Flight.

print_settings.Notes:: Printed in PLA.  Its not really a structural part, so it shouldn't really matter what you use.  Tolerances may vary depending on your printer, but I was able to use this straight from my printer after removing supports.

description.text:
My Delonghi Magnifica EAM3400 wasn't grinding properly, and after a lot of investigation I found that part of the grinder mechanism had broken. Its a small plastic part that has paddles to push the ground coffee out from below the burr grinder. Turns out you can't order replacement parts (you have to get the whole grinder assembly), so I designed a replacement. Its working well, but the test will be to see how long it lasts. If I find problems I'll make revisions and republish. I printed out a few revisions to get the details right as well as the tolerances, but those may vary depending on your 3d printer and material (I used PLA).

Printed the final version using 0.08 layer height to make it smoother, but it probably didn't need that. 25% infill seems to be strong enough, but you could do more if you like.
